{{short description|Any kind of non-baryonic matter}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2016}}
In [[physics]], '''exotic matter''' is [[matter]] that somehow deviates from normal matter and has "exotic" properties. A broader definition of exotic matter is any kind of non-baryonic matter—that is not made of [[baryons]], the subatomic particles (such as [[protons]] and [[neutrons]]) of which ordinary matter is composed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.daviddarling.info/encyclopedia/E/exotic_matter.html|title=Exotic matter|publisher=[[daviddarling.info]]|accessdate=2015-06-24}}</ref> Exotic mass has been considered a colloquial term for matters such as [[dark matter]], [[negative mass]], or [[Mass#Tachyonic particles and imaginary (complex) mass|complex mass]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4517897/nobel-prize-physics-2016/|title=Why 'Exotic Matter' Matters—and Won the Nobel Prize in Physics|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4517897/nobel-prize-physics-2016/|title=Why 'Exotic Matter' Matters—and Won the Nobel Prize in Physics|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/scitech/science/356829/physicists-confirm-existence-of-new-exotic-matter/story/|title=Physicists confirm existence of new 'exotic' matter|work=GMA News Online|access-date=2018-03-27|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/8012-exotic-antimatter-created-earth.html|title=Exotic Antimatter Created on Earth|work=Space.com|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nature.com/nature/supplements/insights/exoticmatter/index.html|title=Exotic matter : Insight : Nature|website=www.nature.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anonymous|date=1998-08-03|title=Focus: Wormhole Construction: Proceed with Caution|url=https://physics.aps.org/story/v2/st7|journal=Physics|language=en-US|volume=2}}</ref>
==Types of exotic matter== There are several types of exotic matter:
* Hypothetical [[subatomic particle|particles]] and states of matter that have "exotic" [[physical property|physical properties]] that would violate known [[laws of physics]], such as a particle having a [[negative mass]]. * [[Hypothetical particle]]s and states of matter that have not yet been encountered, but whose properties would be within the realm of mainstream physics if found to exist. * Several particles whose existence has been experimentally confirmed that are conjectured to be [[exotic hadron]]s and within the [[Standard Model]]. * [[State of matter|States of matter]] that are not commonly encountered, such as [[Bose–Einstein condensate]]s, [[fermionic condensate]]s, [[quantum spin liquid]], [[string-net liquid]], [[supercritical fluid]], [[color-glass condensate]], [[quark–gluon plasma]], [[Rydberg matter]], [[Rydberg polaron]] and [[photonic matter]] but whose properties are entirely within the realm of mainstream physics. * States of matter that are poorly understood, such as [[Dark matter]] and [[Mirror matter]]. * Ordinary matter placed under [[high pressure]], which may result in dramatic changes in its physical or chemical properties. * [[Degenerate matter]] * [[Exotic atoms]]
== Negative mass == {{main article|Negative mass}}
Negative mass would possess some strange properties, such as accelerating in the direction opposite of applied [[force]]. Despite being inconsistent with the expected behavior of "normal" matter, negative mass is mathematically consistent and introduces no violation of [[conservation of momentum]] or [[conservation of energy|energy]]. It is used in certain speculative theories, such as on the construction of artificial [[wormhole]]s and the [[Alcubierre drive]]. The closest known real representative of such exotic matter is the region of pseudo-[[Pressure#Negative pressures|negative-pressure]] density produced by the [[Casimir effect]].
According to [[mass–energy equivalence]], mass <math>m </math> is in proportion to energy <math>E</math> and the coefficient of proportionality is <math>c^2 </math>. Actually, <math>m</math> is still equivalent to <math>E</math> although the coefficient is another constant <ref>{{cite journal |author1=Wang, Z.Y |author2=Wang P.Y |author3=Xu Y.R | date=2011 | title=Crucial experiment to resolve Abraham-Minkowski Controversy | journal=Optik | volume=122 | pages=1994–1996 | doi=10.1016/j.ijleo.2010.12.018 | issue= 22|bibcode = 2011Optik.122.1994W |arxiv=1103.3559 }}</ref> such as <math>-c^2 </math>.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Wang, Z.Y.|title=Modern Theory for Electromagnetic Metamaterials|journal=Plasmonics|date=2016|volume=11|pages=503–508|doi=10.1007/s11468-015-0071-7|issue=2}}</ref> In this case, it is unnecessary to introduce a [[negative energy]] because the mass can be negative although the energy is positive. That is to say,
:<math>E=-mc^2>0</math>
:<math>m= -\frac{E}{c^2}<0</math>
Under the circumstances，
:<math>dE=Fds=\frac{dp}{dt}ds=\frac{ds}{dt}dp=vdp=vd(mv)</math>
:<math>-c^2dm=vd(mv)</math>
:<math>-c^2(2m)dm=2mvd(mv)</math>
:<math>-c^2d(m^2)=d(m^2v^2)</math>
:<math>-m^2c^2=m^2v^2+C</math>
When <math>v=0</math>,
:<math>C=-m_0^2c^2</math>
Consequently,
:<math>-m^2c^2=m^2v^2-m_0^2c^2</math>
:<math>m={m_0\over \sqrt{1+\displaystyle{v^2\over c^2}}}</math>
where <math>m_0<0</math> is [[invariant mass]] and [[invariant energy]] equals <math>E_0=-m_0 c^2>0</math>. The squared mass is still positive and the particle can be stable.
Since <math>m= {m_0\over \sqrt{1+\displaystyle{v^2\over c^2}}}<0</math>,
:<math>p=mv= {m_0 v\over \sqrt{1+\displaystyle{v^2\over c^2}}}<0</math>
The [[negative momentum]] is applied to explain [[negative refraction]], [[inverse Doppler effect]] and [[reverse Cherenkov effect]] observed in a [[negative index metamaterial]]. The [[radiation pressure]] in the [[metamaterial]] is also negative<ref name="Veselago1">{{cite journal|last=Veselago|first=V. G.|title=The electrodynamics of substances with simultaneously negative values of permittivity and permeability|journal=Soviet Physics Uspekhi|year=1968|volume=10|issue=4|pages=509–514 |doi=10.1070/PU1968v010n04ABEH003699|bibcode = 1968SvPhU..10..509V }}</ref> because the force is defined as <math>F=\frac{dp}{dt}</math>. [[Pressure#Negative pressures|Negative pressure]] exists in [[dark energy]] too. Using these above equations, the [[energy-momentum relation]] should be
:<math>E^2 =- p^2c^2+ m_0^2 c^4</math>
Substituting the [[Planck-Einstein relation]] <math>E=\hbar\omega</math> and [[de Broglie]]'s <math>p=\hbar k</math>, we obtain the following [[dispersion relation]]
:<math>\omega^2 =- k^2c^2+ \omega_p^2</math>, <math>(E_0=\hbar\omega_p=-m_0c^2>0)</math>
of the wave consists of a stream of particles whose [[energy-momentum relation]] is <math>E^2 =- p^2c^2+ m_0^2 c^4</math>([[wave–particle duality]]) can be excited in a [[negative index metamaterial]].The velocity of such a particle is equal to
:<math>v=c\sqrt{\frac{E_0^2}{E^2}-1}=c\sqrt{\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}-1}</math>
and range is from zero to infinity
:<math>\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}<2</math>, <math>v<c</math>
:<math>\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}>2</math>, <math>v>c</math>
Moreover, the [[kinetic energy]] is also negative
:<math>E_k = E-E_0=-mc^2-(-m_0 c^2)=-{m_0c^2\over\sqrt{1+\displaystyle{v^2\over c^2}}} + m_0 c^2= m_0 c^2 (1-{1\over\sqrt{1+\displaystyle{v^2\over c^2}}})<0</math>, <math>(m_0<0)</math>
In fact, the [[negative kinetic energy]] exists in some models<ref>{{cite journal|author=Caldwell, R.R.|title=A phantom menace? Cosmological consequences of a dark energy component with super-negative equation of state|journal=Physics Letters B|volume=545|pages=23–29|date=2002|doi=10.1016/S0370-2693(02)02589-3|issue=1–2|arxiv = astro-ph/9908168 |bibcode = 2002PhLB..545...23C }}</ref> to describe [[dark energy]] ([[phantom energy]]) whose pressure is negative. In this way, the [[negative mass]] of exotic matter is now associated with [[negative momentum]], [[Pressure#Negative pressures|negative pressure]], negative kinetic energy and FTL ([[faster-than-light]]).
== Complex mass == {{Main article|Tachyon#Mass}}
A hypothetical particle with [[Complex number|complex]] rest mass would always travel faster than the [[speed of light]]. Such particles are called [[tachyon]]s. There is no confirmed existence of tachyons.
: <math>E = \frac{m\cdot c^2}{\sqrt{1 - \frac{\left|\mathbf{v}\right|^2}{c^2}}}</math>
If the rest mass <math>m</math> is complex this implies that the denominator is complex because the total energy is [[observable]] and thus must be [[real number|real]]. Therefore, the quantity under the square root must be negative, which can only happen if [[speed|''v'']] is greater than [[speed of light|''c'']]. As noted by [[Gregory Benford]] ''et al.,'' [[special relativity]] implies that tachyons, if they existed, could be used to communicate backwards in time<ref>{{cite journal|author1=G. A. Benford |author2=D. L. Book |author3=W. A. Newcomb |year=1970|title=The Tachyonic Antitelephone|journal=[[Physical Review D]]|volume=2 |page=263|doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.2.263|bibcode = 1970PhRvD...2..263B }}</ref> (see [[tachyonic antitelephone]]). Because [[time travel]] is considered to be non-physical, tachyons are believed by physicists either not to exist, or else to be incapable of interacting with normal matter.
In quantum field theory, complex mass would induce [[tachyon condensation]].
== Materials at high pressure == At high pressure, materials such as [[sodium chloride]] (NaCl) in the presence of an excess of either chlorine or sodium were transformed into compounds "forbidden" by classical chemistry, such as {{chem|Na|3|Cl}} and {{chem|Na|Cl|3}}. Quantum mechanical calculations predict the possibility of other compounds, such as {{chem|Na|Cl|7}}, {{chem|Na|3|Cl|2}} and {{chem|Na|2|Cl}}. The materials are thermodynamically stable at high pressures. Such compounds may exist in natural environments that exist at high pressure, such as the deep ocean or inside planetary cores. The materials have potentially useful properties. For instance, {{chem|Na|3|Cl}} is a two-dimensional metal, made of layers of pure sodium and salt that can conduct electricity. The salt layers act as insulators while the sodium layers act as conductors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gizmag.com/scientists-create-forbidden-compounds-table-salt/30520/ |title=Scientists turn table salt into forbidden compounds that violate textbook rules |publisher=Gizmag.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Zhang | first1 = W. | last2 = Oganov | first2 = A. R. | last3 = Goncharov | first3 = A. F. | last4 = Zhu | first4 = Q. | last5 = Boulfelfel | first5 = S. E. | last6 = Lyakhov | first6 = A. O. | last7 = Stavrou | first7 = E. | last8 = Somayazulu | first8 = M. | last9 = Prakapenka | first9 = V. B. | last10 = Konôpková | first10 = Z. | doi = 10.1126/science.1244989 | title = Unexpected Stable Stoichiometries of Sodium Chlorides | journal = Science | volume = 342 | issue = 6165 | pages = 1502–1505 | year = 2013 | pmid = 24357316| pmc = |arxiv = 1310.7674 |bibcode = 2013Sci...342.1502Z }}</ref>

A '''fashion influencer''' is a personality that has a large number of followers on [[social media]].,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.harpersbazaar.com.au/fashion/fashion-influencer-blogger-definition-13357|title=The Difference Between Fashion Influencer And Blogger?|work=Harper's BAZAAR|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en}}</ref> creates mainly [[fashion]] content and has the power to influence the opinion and purchase behavior of others with their recommendations.<ref name=":0"/> Brands endorse them to attend fashion shows, parties, designer dinners<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.harpersbazaararabia.com/people/culture/what-is-the-difference-between-a-fashion-influencer-and-blogger|title=What Is The Difference Between A Fashion Influencer And Blogger?|work=Harper's BAZAAR Arabia|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en}}</ref> and exclusive trips<ref name="Harris">{{Cite news|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/article/what-is-an-influencer|title=What Is An Influencer?|last=Harris|first=Sarah|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> and to wear their clothes on social media. If a salary has been involved, the influencer has to label such posts as paid or sponsored content.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.influencer-secrets.com|title=The Influencer Secrets|website=Influencer Secrets – A Study on the Motivation & Drive of Influencers|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> Before social media "they would have been called '[[It girl]]s'".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.harpersbazaar.com/uk/fashion/fashion-news/news/a41898/fashion-influencer-fashion-blogger-definition/|title=What is the difference between a fashion influencer and blogger?|date=2017-06-05|work=Harper's BAZAAR|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en-GB}}</ref>
To reach influencer status one should obtain at least 10,000 followers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.olapic.com/resources/consumers-follow-listen-trust-influencers_article/|title=Why Consumers Follow, Listen to, and Trust Influencers {{!}} Olapic|work=Olapic {{!}} Visual Commerce & Marketing Platform|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=Spring 2017|title=Influencer Isse: Power Girls. Was wir von Ciara Ferragni, Simone Zippy Stardust, Caro Daur, Stefanie Gieriger & Co. lernen können|url=|journal=GALA STYLE|volume=1|pages=130|via=}}</ref> Depending on the follower size, it is possible to differentiate between micro, maxi and mega influencers.<ref name=":1" /> Micro influencer have around 10,000 loyal followers. Maxi influencers have more than 20,000 and less than 1 million followers. Mega influencers have more than 1 million followers.
Business magazine [[Forbes]] identified fashion influencers as "the new [[celebrity endorsement]]<nowiki/>s". However, influencers seem to have a closer relationship with their audience than traditional celebrities. As marketers [[Jung von Matt]], Brandnew IO and Facelift point out: "Daily interactions across multiple channels, through photos, stories or live sessions, create a form of closeness and trust" that make influencers "often more tangible than traditional celebrities".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.influencer-secrets.com/|title=The Influencer Secrets|website=Influencer Secrets – A Study on the Motivation & Drive of Influencers|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref>
In 2017, [[Forbes]] named [[Chiara Ferragni]], [[Danielle Bernstein]], Julia Engel, Gabi Gregg, [[Jenn Im]], [[Susanna Lau]], Nicolette Mason, [[Simone Zippi Stardust]], Aimee Song and Bryan Yambao ([[Bryanboy]]) the top influencers in the fashion category.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/top-influencers/fashion/#331e64954552|title=Top Influencers of 2017: Fashion|website=Forbes|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref>
== History == In the beginning of 2000, [[fashion blog]]s appeared to be amateurish personal areas. They were created as a hobby by fashion lovers to share their ideas of the latest trends or to get a job in the traditional fashion industry later on.<ref name="Spedding">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/people/meet-fashions-super-influencers-the-women-with-the-power-to-char/|title=Meet fashion's super-influencers: the women with the power to charge £58,000 for one Instagram post|last=Spedding|first=Emma|date=2016-10-06|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-02-24|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> With increasing reach, bloggers learned to monetize their contents. As Pedroni remarks: “fashion blogs evolved from personal diaries kept by fashion lovers, into sophisticated marketing and economic tools”.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pedroni|first=Marco|date=2016|title=Meso-celebrities, fashion and the media: How digital influencers struggle for visibility|url=|journal=Film, Fashion & Consumption|volume=5|pages=103–121|via=}}</ref>
Shortly after, new social media platforms such as [[Instagram]], [[Twitter]], [[Facebook]] and [[YouTube|Youtube]] spread. They enabled bloggers to reach a greater audience and have an even closer relationship with their existing readership.<ref name="Spedding"/> In fact, some bloggers closed their blogs as traffic moved to other platforms such as Instagram.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/article/what-is-an-influencer|title=What Is An Influencer?|last=Harris|first=Sarah|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> According to researcher Emily Hund “Social media’s influencer economy has gained steam quickly in the last few years, particularly on platforms like Instagram and Pinterest, whose image-heavy nature easily lends itself to commerce”.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hund|first=Emily|date=2017-07-28|title=Measured Beauty: Exploring the aesthetics of Instagram's fashion influencers|url=http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3097286.3097330|publisher=ACM|pages=44|doi=10.1145/3097286.3097330|isbn=9781450348478}}</ref> Social media also gave rise to influencers who did not have a blog in the first place. [[Jenn Im]] became a fashion influencer due to her successful Youtube channel,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/top-influencers/fashion/#16bcb9294552),%20Pamela%20Reif%20due%20to%20her%20high%20reach%20on%20Instagram%20(http://aboutpam.com/about|title=Top Influencers of 2017: Fashion|website=Forbes|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> German influencer Pamela Reif due to her high reach on Instagram.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.faz.net/1.5065754|title=Pamela Reif: Fitness-Model und Instagram-Phänomen|last=Wittershagen|first=Michael|date=2017-06-23|work=FAZ.NET|access-date=2018-02-24|last2=Hamburg|language=de|issn=0174-4909}}</ref>
In 2017, Instagram was the social media platform with the highest reach for fashion influencers. [[Forbes]] calculated that the top ten fashion influencers combined generated a reach of 23,3 million on Instagram.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/top-influencers/fashion/#16bcb9294552|title=Top Influencers of 2017: Fashion|website=Forbes|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> At the same time, the fashion industry had the highest share on Instagram influencer marketing in the US.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.influencer-secrets.com|title=The Influencer Secrets|website=Influencer Secrets – A Study on the Motivation & Drive of Influencers|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> It’s share, approximately 61 percent, dominated by far subsequent sectors investing in influencer marketing such as travel (8 percent) and food and drinks (7 percent). The fashion industry spends around €1 billion on sponsored Instagram posts per year.<ref name=":0"/>
== Business == Fashion influencers generate income through brand co-operations and affiliate links.<ref name="Marco 2018">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1013881756|title=Einstieg in das Influencer Marketing : Grundlagen, Strategien und Erfolgsfaktoren|last=Marco|first=Nirschl,|date=2018|others=Steinberg, Laurina|isbn=9783658197452|location=Wiesbaden|oclc=1013881756}}</ref> Principle sources of income are brand co-operations in terms of product placement.<ref name=":0" /> Fashion influencers are paid to pose with specific products on their social media channels and must mark them correspondingly.
The economic value of a fashion influencer is most commonly measured by number of followers. Other key aspects are demographics of their followers, engagement rate and fit between influencer and brand.<ref name="Marco 2018"/><ref name="Harris"/> The latter is the necessary precondition for influencers to work with a brand.<ref name=":0"/> As thousands of people follow them for their authentic personality and style, influencers must be able to identify themselves with the brand in order to recommend it convincingly. Many influencers claim to work exclusively with brands they really like and would recommend in private as well. Influencer Camille Charrière reportedly turned down a 5-digit offer of Macy’s, because she could not identify with the clothes: “At the end of the day, I’m selling my taste and my eye – if I do things off-brand I will lose the respect”.<ref name="Harris"/>
=== Benefits for fashion influencers === Successful fashion influencers generate an income through their social media activities that enables them to quit their jobs and focus solely on their social media career. German fashion influencer Xenia van der Woodsen (xeniaoverdose) left her full-time job at an investment trust, when she realized that she could earn more money with a single Instagram post than working a full day in a regular job.<ref name="Levy">{{Cite news|url=http://www.zeit.de/2017/34/xenia-van-der-woodsen-instagram-influencer-geld|title=Xenia van der Woodsen: Über Geld spricht man nicht|last=Levy|first=Sarah|date=2017-08-21|work=Die Zeit|access-date=2018-02-25|language=de-DE|issn=0044-2070}}</ref>
Until fashion influencer Danielle Bernstein spoke out on her mid-six figures income in 2015, financial information about the influencer business were relatively rare and inconsistent.<ref name="Harper's BAZAAR">{{Cite news|url=https://www.harpersbazaar.com/fashion/trends/a10949/how-bloggers-make-money-on-instagram/|title=How Bloggers Make Money On Instagram|date=2015-05-20|work=Harper's BAZAAR|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en-US}}</ref> In 2017, a study of Jung von Matt, Brandnew IO and Facelift revealed that such a high income is relatively rare among influencers.<ref name=":0"/> Only eight out of the 1,200 interviewed influencers earn in average between $10,000 – 25,000 per campaign and only three of them more than $25,000. Albeit the “leading fashion influencers in Germany make over one million in revenue each year”, the majority makes less than $1,000 per campaign.
A majority of influencers receive a salary. Solely a minority of 20 percent makes brand co-operations in exchange for giveaways.<ref name=":0"/> The salary primarily depends on the number of followers.<ref name="Harper's BAZAAR"/> The higher the follower number, the higher the salary range. The price for a cooperation depends also on the contract terms, for example if it concerns a one-time Instagram post or a long-term partnership including several posts. Xenia van der Woodsen, one of Germany’s top three fashion influencers in 2017,<ref name=":0"/> accepts only long-term brand co-operations in the majority of cases.<ref name="Levy"/> In her experience, posts of long-term campaigns appear more authentic and credible, whereas single paid content pieces stand out as advertisement.
==== Affiliate links ==== Affiliate links enable fashion influencers to earn money on commission. The procedure was introduced by Amber Venz Box in 2011 with her rewardStyle program.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/sboyd/2014/09/30/rewardstyle-and-liketoknowit-founder-amber-venz-box-is-changing-the-retailing-industr/#77e40fdef11f|title=RewardStyle And LIKEtoKNOWit Founder Amber Venz Box Is Changing The Retailing Industry|last=Boyd|first=Sarah|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en}}</ref> RewardStyle enables selected bloggers to place individual links on their blog posts that lead consumers to a website where they can directly shop the look. If a costumer buys something in the shop, the influencer gets a sales commission. When lots of traffic started to shift to Instagram, this technique did not work anymore, because Instagram did not allow links in post descriptions and images. Bonx created a new app for Instagram, Snapchat and Pinterest in 2014 – LIKEtoKNOW.it.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/digital/how-these-3-tech-companies-revamped-their-products-to-improve-the-customer-experience/|title=How These 3 Tech Companies Revamped Their Products to Improve the Customer Experience|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en-US}}</ref> Since March 2017, users can take a screenshot of an influencer's picture and LIKEtoKNOW.it delivers the ready-to-shop product details via the app.
=== Benefits for fashion brands === Fashion brands use the reach and positive reputation of influencers by implementing [[influencer marketing]]. Influencers spread brand messages, increase brand awareness, contribute to a positive brand image and increase sales by tagging fashion brands in their posts.<ref name=":0"/>
Although data that shows the direct correlation between influencer campaigns and sales are rare, the success of affiliate platforms as rewardStyle and successful examples such as the #mangogirls campaign, indicate that influencer engagement affects sales. In the #mangogirls campaign several influencers had independently chosen the same coat as their favorite piece of the Mango collection and showcased it on Instagram.<ref name="Harris"/> The coat went viral and sold-out. In fact, first studies show that every third consumer has already bought a product following the recommendation of an influencer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20171214005418/en/Survey-Consumers-Swayed-Social-Influencers-Purchase-Product|title=Survey: Nearly One Third of Consumers Have Been Swayed by Social Influencers to Purchase a Product or Service|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en}}</ref>
== Criticism == Fashion influencers have been criticized by journalists for their lack of transparency on [[sponsored post]]<nowiki/>s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/oct/05/social-media-stars-breaching-rules-on-promoting-brands-watchdog-says-instagram-twitter|title=Social media stars breaching rules on promoting brands, watchdog says|last=Marsh|first=Sarah|date=2017-10-05|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> The lines between posts in which influencers share product recommendations for free or because they are paid for it are often blurred.<ref name="Bloomberg.com">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-14/instagram-to-make-it-clearer-when-influencer-posts-are-paid-ads|title=Instagram to Make It Clearer When Influencer Posts Are Paid Ads|date=2017-06-14|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en}}</ref> Influencers are supposed to mark a sponsored post with hashtags such as #ad or #sponsored, but often use less-obvious hashtags like #sp or non at all.
Due to this lack of transparency, the U.S. [[Federal Trade Commission]] (FTC) sent out dozens of warning letters to Instagram influencers in the beginning of 2017, giving further indications to influencers and marketers on how to disclose advertising and sponsored posts. Following the rules of the FTC, hashtags like #ad have to appear before the "more" button and are not allowed to be buried in a flood of other hashtags.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2017/04/ftc-staff-reminds-influencers-brands-clearly-disclose|title=FTC Staff Reminds Influencers and Brands to Clearly Disclose Relationship|date=2017-04-18|work=Federal Trade Commission|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en}}</ref> Thus, "anyone endorsing a brand must "clearly and conspicuously" declare connections to it, for example if products have been given free, if a payment has been made for the endorsement or if there is a business or family relationship".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-39650580|title=Celebrities warned over Instagram ads|date=2017-04-20|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en-GB}}</ref>
in June 2017, Instagram launched a new disclosure system with which users can tag sponsors in a post. If the brand confirms the commercial relation, the post is marked with a "paid partnership" tag at the top<ref name="Bloomberg.com"/>
=== See also === * [[Fashion blog]] * [[Instagram model]]s * [[Chiara Ferragni]] * [[Influencer marketing]] * [[Affiliate marketing]] * [[Product placement]] * [[Celebrity branding]] * [[Fashion]]

{{primary sources|date=October 2009}} '''Female perversion''' is a term coined by [[Estela V. Welldon]] in 1992 to refer to women who commit violence, either against themselves or against others.Welldon, E.V. 1991 ''Psychology and psychopathology in women - a psychoanalytic perspective'', '''[[British Journal of Psychiatry]]''' 158 pg 85-92[[Estela V. Welldon|Welldon, E.V.]] 1992 ''Mother, Madonna, Whore: The Idealization and Denigration of Motherhood'' [[Free Association Books]], 1988 Though the term can be used [[pejorative]]ly and sometimes has sexual connotations, its strict definition is an instance of [[human behavior]] that deviates from what is considered [[Orthodoxy|orthodox]] or [[normality (behavior)|normal]], and it is in this sense that the term is used by psychologists. The term is also controversial as according to Welldon there is a prevailing denial of the existence of female violence, throughout the legal and mental health community.Motz, Anna 2001 ''The psychology of female violence: crimes against the body {{ISBN|978-0415126755}}'' pg 3 ==Model of female perversion== Welldon (1992) put forward a model of female perversion that introduced the term into the psychological nomenclature. The model covers several categories of violent behavior that can be directed at one's own body, against children, or against adults. Freudian psychoanalytic theory suggested that perversion fell solely within the male domain, that it was related to the [[phallus]], and that aggressive drive was unique to men. In her book ''Madonna, Whore: The Idealisation and Denigration of Motherhood'', Welldon challenges this notion, and argues that women are equally capable of perversion. Though they do not use the [[penis]] with violence, they instead use the whole body.
"In doing so, they attack the whole body, and sometimes by extension the bodies of children. They are symbolically wreaking revenge on their own internalised, often cruel and perverse mother. They identify their own body with the body of the mother. Likewise when they attack their children, they express violence towards a [[narcissistic]] extension of themselves" (Motz, 2001)Motz, Anna 2001 ''The psychology of female violence: crimes against the body'' pg 16
The major forms it can manifest itself are Motz, Anna 2001 ''The psychology of female violence: crimes against the body'' pg 5-8 * [[self-harm]] * [[eating disorders]] * physical and sexual abuse of children * [[infanticide]] * [[Munchausen syndrome by proxy]] * physical or sexual assault of others, including battered women who kill Welldon argues that it can be seen as a form of sexualised aggression, and challenges the Freudian view that violence is a uniquely male phallic expression.
The reproductive functions and organs are used by both sexes to express perversion. Perverse men use their penises to attack and show hatred towards symbolic sources of humiliation..... If perversion in the man is focused through his penis, in the woman it will similarly expressed through her reproductive organs and the maternal representations of motherhood (Welldon 1991)
[[Anna Motz]], in her book ''The psychology of female violence'' suggests that the expression of this anger on the body or that of another is a communicative act, clearly sending a message of internal pain or of psychosis (Motz, 2001).Motz, Anna 2001 ''The psychology of female violence: crimes against the body'' pg 6 She calls the message "the language of the body", and that the symbolic use of violence against the body can be likened to psychosomatic illness. ===Violence against the self=== Violence against the self can take several forms, including deprivation and starvation as is the case in [[anorexia nervosa]] and [[bulimia]], [[self-injury]] or suicide attempts, or other forms of self-harm. ===Violence against children=== Violence against children often goes unreported, and is largely hidden from view. It can take the form of direct physical or sexual assault, [[Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy]], or [[infanticide]]. Often the capacity of women to commit violence against children is denied, in the refusal to 'think the unthinkable'.Motz, Anna 2001 ''The psychology of female violence: crimes against the body'' pg 9 ===Violence against adults=== Violence against others can take many forms, from domestic assault, physical assault, and when it escalates in the form of [[homicide]] and/or [[infanticide]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.crimes-against-the-body.com Anna Motz's website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Female Perversion}} [[Category:Women in society]] [[Category:Violence]]

[[Image:Trident C4 first launch.jpg|thumb|The term '''ICBM address''' is derived from the [[intercontinental ballistic missile|ICBM]] or [[intercontinental ballistic missile]].]]
'''ICBM''' ('''intercontinental ballistic missile''') '''address''' or '''missile address''' is [[Hacker (programmer subculture)|hacker]] [[slang]] for one's [[longitude]] and [[latitude]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/42329393|title=The new hacker's dictionary|date=1996|publisher=MIT Press|others=Raymond, Eric S.|isbn=9780262680929|edition=3rd|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|oclc=42329393|page=253}}</ref> (preferably to [[arcsecond|seconds-of-arc]] accuracy) when placed in a [[signature block|signature]] or another publicly available file.
== Origin == The form that used to register a site with the [[Usenet]] [[map]]ping project, before [[Internet]] connectivity became commonplace for Usenet sites, included a field for [[longitude]] and [[latitude]], preferably to [[arcsecond|seconds-of-arc]] accuracy. This was actually used for generating geographically-correct maps of [[Usenet]] links on a plotter; however, it became traditional to refer to this as one's [[ICBM]] address or missile address, and some people include it in their [[signature block|sig block]] with that name (but a real missile address would include target [[elevation#Geography|elevation]]).
A typical tag might read "ICBM Address: 36.8274040 N, 108.0204086 W".
== Modern use == Today, using the ICBM method of coordinates is one method of [[geotagging]] webpages or other online material. Some projects parse ICBM address included in [[webpage]]s via [[meta tags]], which can then be used to map out sites added to its [[database]].
Web page uses of <syntaxhighlight lang="html4strict" enclose="none"><meta name="ICBM" content="12.345, 67.890"></syntaxhighlight><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/MetaExtensions|title=MetaExtensions|website=WHATWG Wiki|access-date=2017-10-27}}</ref> specify the same location as a [[Geo URI|geo:12.345,67.890]] URI.
== See also == *[[Geographic coordinate system]] *[[LOC record]] *[[Geo (microformat)]] *[[Geotagging#ICBM method|Geotagging]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.catb.org/~esr/jargon/html/I/ICBM-address.html Jargon File ICBM Address Entry] {{JargonFile}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Other uses|Incontinence (disambiguation)}} '''Incontinence''' ("a want of continence or self-restraint") is often used by philosophers to translate the Greek term [[Akrasia]] (ἀκρασία). Used to refer to a lacking in moderation or self-control, especially related to sexual desire,<ref>dictionary.com – [http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/incontinence incontinence]</ref> incontinence may also be called '''wantonness'''.
==Aristotle== [[Aristotle]] devoted book VII of the [[Nicomachean Ethics]] to the discussion of continence and incontinence, having previously linked the latter both to [[Spendthrift|prodigality]] in its effects, and to those dominated by irrational feeling in its failure to obey knowledge of the good:<ref>J. A. K. Thompson trans, ''The Ethics of Aristotle'' (1976) pp. 142, 66, and 89</ref> a case of knowing [[virtue]], but not having habituated it to control [[Passion (emotion)|passion]].
Aristotle considered one could be incontinent with respect to money or temper or glory, but that its core relation was to bodily enjoyment.<ref>Thompson, p. 235-9</ref> Its causes could be weakness of will, or an impetuous refusal to think.<ref>Thompson, p. 244</ref> At the same time, he did not consider it a vice, because it is not so much a product of moral choice, but instead, a failure to act on one's better knowledge.<ref>Thompson, p. 244-6</ref>
==Later developments==
For Augustine, incontinence was not so much a problem of knowledge (knowing but not acting) but of the [[Will (philosophy)|will]]: he considered it a matter of everyday experience that men incontinently choose lesser over greater goods.<ref>Carl Mitcham, ''Thinking Through Technology'' (1994) p. 263-4</ref>
In the structural division of [[Inferno (Dante)|Dante's ''Inferno'']], incontinence is the sin punished in the second through fifth circles.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Durling|first1=Robert M.|last2=Martinez|first2=Ronald L.|page=178|title=Inferno|series=The Divine Comedy of Dante Alighieri|volume=1|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|year=1996|isbn=9780195087444}}</ref> The mutual incontinence of lust was for Dante the lightest of the deadly sins,<ref>Dante, p. 101-2</ref> even if its lack of self-control would open the road to deeper layers of Hell.
Akrasia appeared later as a character in Spenser's [[The Faerie Queene]], representing the incontinence of lust, followed in the next canto by a study of that of anger;<ref>[[Edmund Spenser]], ''The Fairie Queen'' (1978) p. lxiv</ref> and as late as [[Jane Austen]] the [[sensibility]] of such figures as [[Marianne Dashwood]] would be treated as a form of (spiritual) incontinence.<ref>Claire Harman, ''Jane's Fame'' (2007) p. 126</ref>
With the triumph of [[Romanticism]], however, the incontinent choice of feeling over reason became increasingly valorised in Western culture.<ref>Mitcham, p. 265–56</ref> [[William Blake|Blake]] wrote that "those who restrain desire, do so because theirs is weak enough to be restrained".<ref>Quoted in M. H. Abrams, ''The Mirror and the Lamp'' (1971) p. 251</ref> Encouraged by [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau|Rousseau]], there was a rise of what [[Arnold J. Toynbee]] would describe as "an ''abandon'' (ακρατεια)...a state of mind in which [[antinomianism]] is accepted – consciously or unconsciously, in theory or in practice – as a substitute for creativeness".<ref>Arnold J. Toynbee, ''[[A Study of History]]'' (1939) v5 p. 377 and p. 399</ref>
A peak of such acrasia was perhaps reached in the 1960s cult of letting it all hang out – of breakdown, acting out and emotional self-indulgence and drama.<ref>Jenny Diski, ''The Sixties'' (2009) p. 120-1</ref> Partly in reaction, the proponents of [[emotional intelligence]] would look back to Aristotle in the search for impulse control and [[Gratification|delayed gratification]]<ref>Daniel Goleman, ''Emotional Intelligence'' (1996) pp. 80–83 and p. xiv</ref> – to his dictum that "a person is called continent or incontinent according as his reason is or is not in control".<ref>Thompson, p. 302</ref>
==See also== * [[Akrasia]] *[[Seven deadly sins]]
==References== {{reflist|2|}}
==Further reading== *Dahl, N.O. 1984. ''Practical Reason, Aristotle, and the Weakness of Will''. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press. *Wedin, M. 1988. ''Mind and Imagination in Aristotle''. New Haven: Yale University Press.
==External links== {{wikiquote}} {{Wiktionary|incontinence}} *[http://www.philosophypages.com/hy/2s.htm Aristotle: Ethics and the Virtues (Weakness of the Will)] *[http://nothingistic.org/library/aristotle/nicomachean/index.html#b7 Aristotle: Nicomachean Ethics, Book VII]

[[File:Jeremy Lent pic.jpg|thumb|Jeremy Lent]] {{Infobox person | name = Jeremy Lent | image = | birth_date = 1960 | birth_place = London, UK | education = Cambridge University University of Chicago | organization = Liology Institute | website = https://www.jeremylent.com https://www.patternsofmeaning.com http://www.liology.org }}
'''Jeremy Lent''' (born 1960) is an author whose writings investigate the patterns of thought that have led civilization to its current crisis of sustainability. He is the founder of the non-profit Liology Institute, which is dedicated to a worldview that could enable humanity to thrive sustainably. He is the author of ''The Patterning Instinct'' and ''Requiem of the Human Soul''.<ref name=":0" /> Earlier in his career, Lent was the founder, chairman and CEO of the internet company [[NextCard]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasdaq.com/markets/ipos/filing.ashx?filingid=899887|title=NEXTCARD INC (Form: S-1/A, Received: 04/30/1999 09:49:46)|website=www.nasdaq.com|access-date=2017-04-19}}</ref>
== Early life == Lent was born and raised in [[London]]. He graduated from the [[University College School]] and earned an undergraduate degree in [[English literature|English Literature]] at [[Emmanuel College, Cambridge|Emmanuel College]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]] in 1981.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.jeremylent.com/|title=Website of Jeremy Lent – Author of The Patterning Instinct|website=Jeremy Lent Author and Integrator|access-date=2017-04-19}}</ref> Lent left the UK to live in the United States. In 1986, he earned an [[MBA]] from the [[University of Chicago]].<ref name=":0" /> He is married and currently lives in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]].
In addition to his writing, Lent is a practitioner of meditation, [[Qigong]], and [[Tai chi|Tai Chi]]. He is a Level II certified teacher of Radiant Heart Qigong.
== Career == Lent joined Strategic Planning Associates, a strategy consulting company based in Washington, D.C. In 1989, he joined First Deposit Corporation (later renamed [[Providian]]), a direct mail [[credit card]] company in San Francisco. Lent was named [[Chief financial officer|Chief Financial Officer]] of Providian in 1991 and left the company in 1994.<ref name=":2" />
In 1996, Lent founded [[NextCard]], an internet [[financial services]] company. NextCard was the first company to enable consumers to apply for a credit card over the internet and be approved in real time and the first company to offer consumers the ability to design their own card by uploading a personalized image during the application process.<ref name=":2" />
As chairman and CEO, Lent took NextCard public in 1999 and led a secondary offering in 2000. However, due to his first wife’s illness, Lent stepped down as CEO later in 2000, to care for her.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestreet.com/story/1012883/1/nextcard-mixes-good-news-quicker-profitability-with-bad-ceos-departure.html|title=NextCard Mixes Good News, Quicker Profitability, With Bad, CEO's Departure|last=Eavis|first=Peter|date=2000-07-24|work=TheStreet|access-date=2017-04-28|language=en-US}}</ref> After Lent’s departure, NextCard suffered serious setbacks. It was announced in late 2001, that the company was undercapitalized, and it was taken over by the [[Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation]] (FDIC) in 2002. Along with the other board members, Lent was involved for several years in shareholder lawsuits and investigations by the FDIC and [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC). These were eventually settled, and in 2005 the SEC dismissed fraud charges that it had levied against Lent.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/litigation/litreleases/2006/lr19903.htm|title=Jeremy R. Lent, et al.: Lit. Rel. No. 19903 / November 8, 2006|website=www.sec.gov|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref>
== Writing ==
=== ''The Patterning Instinct'' === ''The Patterning Instinct: A Cultural History of Humanity’s Search for Meaning'' ([[Prometheus Books]], May 2017) is a cognitive history of humanity, tracing how different cultures patterned meaning into the universe and how that has affected history. The result of ten years of research, the book offers a thesis that “culture shapes values and those values shape history.”<ref name=":0" />
This approach is in contrast to the predominant [[Geographic determinism|geographic determinist]] approach to history, exemplified by historians such as [[Jared Diamond]], [[Ian Morris (historian)|Ian Morris]] and [[Kenneth Pomeranz]]. Lent argues that “The cognitive frames through which different cultures perceive reality have had a profound effect on their historical direction. The worldview of a given civilization—the implicit beliefs and values that create a pattern of meaning in people’s lives—has, in my opinion, been a significant driver of the historical path each civilization has taken.”<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lent|first=Jeremy|date=|title=Patterning Instinct|url=|journal=Origins: The Bulletin of the International Big History Association|volume=VI|pages=17–24}}</ref>
The book conducts what Lent calls an “archaeological exploration of the mind,” using findings from [[cognitive science]] and [[systems theory]] to reveal the implicit layers of values that form cultural norms. In a departure from the mainstream science-religion debate, ''The Patterning Instinct'' shows how medieval Christian rationalism acted as an incubator for scientific thought, which in turn, shaped the modern vision of the “conquest of nature.” Evaluating the sustainability crisis, Lent argues that it is culturally driven: a product of particular patterns that could be reshaped.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://edelweiss.abovethetreeline.com/ProductDetailPage.aspx?sequence=18&group=catalog&mailingID=0&mailingGroupID=0&catalogID=4016922&org=&sku=1633882934|title=The Patterning Instinct|website=edelweiss.abovethetreeline.com|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref>
The book concludes by exploring scenarios for humanity’s future, foreseeing a coming struggle between two contrasting views: one driving to a technological world of artificially enhanced humans, the other enabling a sustainable future arising from intrinsic connectedness among people and to the natural world.<ref name=":1" />
''The Patterning Instinct'' contains a foreword by [[Fritjof Capra]]. Prior to publication, the book received favorable endorsements from notables such as [[Paul R. Ehrlich|Paul Ehrlich,]] [[Thom Hartmann]], Rick Hanson, [[J. R. McNeill]], and [[Jonathon Porritt]].<ref name=":0" /> Guardian journalist, George Monbiot, has called it "the most profound and far-reaching book I have ever read."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.monbiot.com/2018/01/31/stepping-back-from-the-brink/|title=Stepping Back from the Brink|work=George Monbiot|access-date=2018-04-03|language=en-US}}</ref> The book received a Silver Award from [http://nautilusbookawards.com/2017-silver-winners/ Nautilus Book Awards] in April, 2018 in the Social Sciences & Education category.
=== ''Requiem of the Human Soul'' === Beginning around 2005, Lent began an inquiry into the various constructions of meaning formed by cultures around the world and throughout history. The first expression of this investigation was his science fiction novel, ''Requiem of the Human Soul'' (Libros Libertad, 2009)..
The novel is set in the late 22nd century when most people are genetically enhanced. The minority that remains genetically unadulterated, known as Primals, consists mostly of the impoverished global underclass. The UN is holding a hearing in New York to consider whether to make the Primals extinct. The novel is written from the viewpoint of a Primal, Eusebio, who has been picked to represent his race in a last-ditch legal effort to save the Primals from extinction.
The novel raises questions about spirituality, history and global politics: Can the human race enhance itself to a higher plane? At what cost and benefit? If some “essence” of humanity was lost as a result, would that be so bad, given our sordid and shameful history? On the other hand, is there something special—a human soul—worth keeping at any price? Ultimately, the novel invites the reader to grapple with a fundamental question: what does it mean to be human?<ref>{{Cite book|title=Requiem of the Human Soul|last=Lent|first=Jeremy|publisher=Libros Libertad|year=2009|isbn=|location=Vancouver|pages=}}</ref>
== Liology Institute == Lent founded the nonprofit Liology Institute in 2012, with the aim of fostering a worldview that could enable humanity to thrive sustainably. The institute, according to its website, “is dedicated to fostering a worldview in which the human discovery and experience of meaning in our lives is compatible with the findings of scientific investigation, offering a deeply integrated and coherent understanding of humanity’s place in our cosmos which could enable us to thrive on our planet harmoniously and sustainably.”<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.liology.org/|title=The Liology Institute|website=The Liology Institute|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref>
Lent coined the term "liology" from the Chinese word ''[[Li (Neo-Confucianism)|li]],'' meaning organizing principles of the universe, and “ology” of Greek etymology meaning “the study of.” The institute is intended to integrate traditional East Asian practices with the findings of modern systems science.
Its stated objectives are to: * Stimulate and encourage a deep integration of scientific rigor with spiritual meaning. * Distill East Asian spiritual traditions and integrate them with findings in systems biology, complexity science and neuroscience. * Replace the mind/body duality of conventional Western thought with a concept that value is intrinsic to our experience. * Join the worldwide movement towards achieving a sustainable way of living. * Adopt an interdisciplinary approach to understanding humanity's history, current condition and trajectory. * Cultivate skills that promote integration within a person and harmonization between humanity and the natural world.<ref name=":3" /> In 2014, the institute began an annual series of workshops, exploring how the values and insights of Liology apply to people’s everyday lives.
== Great Transformation == Lent asserts that humanity is entering a period of transformation, of a scale that has occurred twice before in history: the [[First agricultural revolution|Agricultural Revolution]] twelve thousand years ago, and the [[Scientific revolution|Scientific]] and [[Industrial Revolution]]<nowiki/>s several hundred years ago. The trajectories he consider include a [[collapse of civilization]], a [[Posthumanism|posthuman]] techno society and sustainable human flourishing (a "Great Transformation").
Lent claims that, to secure the latter humanity needs a new suite of values based on a sense of intrinsic connectedness. These values emphasize: * Quality of life, rather than material possessions * Political, social, and economic choices based on shared humanity * Environmentally sustainable societies.<ref>“The Great Transformation, Or How We (Just) Avoided a Climate Catastrophe: A historian in 2050 looks back at the first half of the century.” Presented at the UC Santa Barbara virtual conference: ''The World In 2050: Creating/Imagining Just Climate Futures.'' October 2016</ref>
